Constitution of India - Arts. 300-A, 14, 19 and 21 Foreign investment/FOi - Property of foreign investor within territory of India - Deprivation of - Protection available to foreign investor - Held, even if the foreign investor has no fundamental rights, he must know, that rule of law prevails in India The Roerichs owned Tatgunni Estate covering a large area, a part of which had been granted to them by the State Government in the year 1954 for linaloe cultivation. The Roerichs sold to the appellant Company part of the said land including the land granted under Section 107(1)(vi) of the Karnataka Land Reforms Act, 1961 (the Land Reforms Act) for linaloe cultivation. Subsequently, the Government issued a Notification dated 8-3-1994 under Section 110 of the Land Reforms Act, withdrawing the exemption granted for the lands used for cultivation of linaloe. Challenging the constitutionality of the Roerich and Devikarani Roerich Estate (Acquisition and Transfer) Act, 1996 (the Acquisition Act) the appellant Company contended that the concept of eminent domain and its key components viz. public purpose and adequate compensation should be read into Article 300-A as well as List III Entry 42. That the impugned Act did not provide for any principle or guidelines for the fixation of the compensation amount and the amount fixed was illusory, compared to the value of the property taken away from the Company in exercise of the powers of eminent domain. That the said Act was therefore, liable to be challenged as violative of Articles 14, 19 and 21 of the Constitution and on the principle of the rule of law, which is the basic structure of the Constitution. That the various judicial pronouncements of the Supreme Court in respect of Articles 19(1 )(f), 31 ( 1) and 31 (2) of the Constitution were useful guides for interpreting Article 300-A and the impugned Act. That the twin requirements of public purpose and compensation though not incorporated in Article 300-A, when a person was deprived of his property, a constitutional court could always examine the validity of the statute on those grounds. The appellants further contended that the impugned Act did not contain any provision for protection of agrarian reforms and hence, was not protected by Article 31-A and hence not saved from challenges on the ground of violation of Articles 14 and 19 of the Constitution. That the management and protection of land used for linaloe cultivation and the preservation of artefacts, paintings, etc. were not part of agrarian reforms. That the impugned Act was ex facie repugnant to the provisions of the Land Acquisition Act, 1894 and hence void under Article 254(1) due to want of the Presidential assent. The appellants challenged the validity of Section 110 of the Land Reforms Act and the Notification dated 8-3-1994 primarily on the ground of excessive delegation of legislative powers on the State Government. They further contended that the omission on the part of the respondent State to lay the notification in accordance with Section 140 of the Act for approval by the legislature was an incurable illegality. Opposing the appeals, the respondent State contended, inter alia, that since Article 19(1)(/), Articles 31 (1) and 31 (2) were consciously omitted, the intention of Parliament was to limit the doctrine of eminent domain which highlights the principles of public purpose and compensation. That moreover, the adequacy of the amount fixed by the legislature was not amenable to judicial review. ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Modak, (2008) 1 SCC 1 paras 61, 62 & 63. this judgment is protected by the law declared by the Supreme Court in Eastern Book Company v. (Para 168) Deprivation of property by statute within the meaning of Article 300-A, generally speaking, must take place for public purpose or public interest. The concept of eminent domain which applies when a person is deprived of his prope1iy postulates that the purpose must be p1imarily public and not primarily of p1ivate interest and merely incidentally beneficial to the public. Any law, which deprives a person of his private property for private interest, will be unlawful and unfair and undermines the rule of law and can be subjected to judicial review. But the question as to whether the purpose is primaiily public or private, has to be decided by the legislature, which of course should be made known. (Paras 180 and 182) The concept of "public purpose" has been given fairly expansive meaning which has to be justified upon the purpose and object of the statute and the policy of the legislation. Public purpose is, therefore, a condition precedent, for deprivation of a person from his property under Article 300-A. [Paras 181 and 221(e)] The only safe and correct way of construing the statute is to apply the plain meaning of the words. Schedule VII List III Entry 42 has used the words "acquisition" and "requisitioning", but Article 300-A has used the expression "deprivation", though the word "deprived" or "deprivation" takes in its fold "acquisition" and "requisitioning", the initial presumption is in favour of the literal meaning since Parliament is taken to mean as it says. (Para 185) The various entries in Schedule VII List III are not "powers" of legislation but "fields" of legislation. Moreover, Article 245 of the Constitution is the fountain source of legislative power. (Para 186) Hoechst Pharmaceuticals Ltd. v. State of Bihar, (1983) 4 SCC 45 : 1983 SCC (Tax) 248; State of W.B. v. Kesoram Industries Ltd., (2004) 10 SCC 201, reiterated and followed State of Madras v. Gannon Dunkerley & Co. (Madras) Ltd., AIR 1958 SC 560 : 1959 SCR 379, considered There is no appai·ent conflict in the words used in List III Entry 42 so as to infer that the payment of compensation is inbuilt or inherent in the words "acquisition and requisitioning" under List III Entry 42. Right to claim compensation, therefore, cannot be read into the legislative List III Entry 42. (Para 188) Requirement of public purpose, for deprivation of a person of his property under Article 300-A, is a precondition, but no compensation or nil compensation or its illusiveness has to be justified by the State on judicially justiciable standards. Measures designed to achieve greater social justice, may call for lesser compensation and such a limitation by itself will not make legislation invalid or unconstitutional or confiscatory. In other words, the right to claim compensation or the obligation to pay, though not expressly included in Article 300-A, it can be inferred in Article 300-A and it is for the State to justify its stand on justifiable grounds which may depend upon the legislative policy, object and purpose of the statute and host of other factors. STATE OF KARNATAKA 5 Article 300-A would be equally violated if the provisions of law authorising deprivation of property have not been complied with. While enacting Article 300-A Parliament has only bon-owed Article 31 ( 1) (the "Rule of Law" doctrine) and not A1ticle 31(2) (which had embodied the doctrine of eminent domain). Article 300-A enables the State to put restrictions on the right to property by law. That law has to be reasonable. It must comply with other provisions of the Constitution. The limitation or restriction should not be arbitrary or excessive or what is beyond what is required in public interest. The limitation or restriction must not be disproportionate to the situation or excessive. (Para 190) The legislation providing for deprivation of property under Article 300-A must be "just, fair and reasonable" as understood in terms of Articles 14, 19(1)(g), 26(b), 30(1-A), etc. Thus in each case, courts will have to examine the scheme of the impugned Act, its object, purpose as also the question whether payment of nil compensation or nominal compensation would make the impugned law unjust, unfair or unreasonable in terms of other provisions of the Constitution as indicated herein. [Paras 191 and 221 ( e)] There is a difference between "no" compensation and "nil" compensation. A law seeking to acquire private property for public purpose cannot say that "no compensation shall be paid". However, there could be a law awarding "nil" compensation in cases where the State unde1takes to discharge the liabilities charged on the property under acquisition and onus is on the Government to establish validity of such law. In the latter case, the court in exercise of judicial review will test such a law keeping in mind the said parameters. (Para 192) Acquisition of property for a public purpose may meet with a lot of contingencies, like deprivation of livelihood, leading to violation of Article 21, but that per se is not a ground to strike down a statute or its provisions. (Para 202) Pleas of unreasonableness, arbitrariness, lack of proportionality, etc. always raise an element of subjectivity on which a court cannot strike down a statute or a statutory provision, especially when the right to property is no more a fundamental right. Otherwise the comt will be substituting its wisdom for that of the legislature, which is impermissible in constitutional democracy. (Para 205) Jilubhai Nanbhai Khachar v. State of Kerala, AIR 1961 SC 552, considered Maneka Gandhi V. Union of India, (1978) 1 sec 248, cited In the present case, the impugned Act has got the assent of the President as required under the proviso to Article 31-A(l ), hence, it is immune from challenge on the ground of arbitrariness and unreasonableness under Article 14 of the Constitution of India. But in a given case, if a statute [protected by Article 31-A] violates the rnle of law or the basic strncture of the Constitution, it will not be immune from challenge under Article 32 and Article 226 of the Constitution of India. (Paras 208 and 210) Statutes are many which though deprive a person of his property, have the protection of Articles 31-A, 31-B, 31-C and hence are immune from challenge under Article 19 or Article 14. In I.R. Coelho case, (2007) 2 SCC 1, the basic structure was defined in terms of fundamental rights as reflected under Articles 14, 15, 19, 20, 21 and 32. In that case the Court held that statutes mentioned in Schedule IX are immune from challenge on the ground of violation of fundamental rights, but if such laws violate the basic structure, they no longer enjoy the immunity offered by Schedule IX. State of Maharashtra, (1998) 2 SCC 1, referred to The rule of law as a concept finds no place in the Constitution, but has been characterised as a basic feature of the Constitution which cannot be abrogated or destroyed even by Parliament and in fact binds Parliament. The rule of law is one of the most important aspects of the doctrine of basic structure. The rule of law affirms Parliament's supremacy while at the same time denying it sovereignty over the Constitution. (Para 211) Kesavananda Bharati v. State of Kerala, (1973) 4 SCC 225,followed The rule of law can be traced back to Aristotle and has been championed by Roman jurists, medieval natural law thinkers, Enlightenment philosophers such as Hobbes, Locke, Rousseau, Montesquieu, Dicey, etc. The rule of law has also been accepted as the basic principle of the Canadian Constitution. The rule of law has been considered to be as an implied limitation on Parliament's powers to legislate. (Paras 212 to 216) Manitoba Language Rights, In re, (1985) 1 SCR 721 (Can SC); Resolution to Amend the Constitution, In re, (1981) 1 SCR 753 (Can SC); OPSEU v. Ontario (Attorney General), (1987) 2 SCR 2 (Can SC), affirmed Alberta Statutes, In re, 1938 SCR 100 (Can SC); Switzman v. Elbling, 1957 SCR 285 (Can SC), cited The rule of law as a principle contains no explicit substantive component like eminent domain but has many shades and colours. Violation of principle of natural justice may undermine the rule of law resulting in arbitrariness, unreasonableness, etc. but such violations may not unde1mine the rule of law so as to invalidate a statute. Violation must be of such a se1ious nature which unde1mines the very basic structure of the Constitution and the democratic principles of India. But once the court finds, a statute undermines the rule of law which has the status of a constitutional principle like the basic structure, the said grounds are also available and not vice versa. Any law which, in the opinion of the court, is not just, fair and reasonable, is not a ground to strike down a statute because such an approach would always be subjective, not the will of the people, because there is always a presumption of constitutionality for a statute. (Para 217) The rule of law as a principle is not an absolute means of achieving equality, human rights, justice, freedom and even democracy and it all depends upon the nature of the legislation and the seriousness of the violation. (Para 218) One of the fundamental principles of a democratic society inherent in all the provisions of the Constitution is that any inte1ference with the peaceful enjoyment of possession should be lawful. Therefore, it is declared that the rule of law exists in India even when the Court interprets a statute, which has the blessings of Article 300-A. (Para 219) Deprivation of property may also cause serious concern in the area of foreign investment, especially in the context of international law and international investment agreements. Whenever, a foreign investor operates within the territory of a host country the investor and its properties are subject to the legislative control of the host country, along with the international treaties or agreements. Even if the foreign investor has no fundamental right, he must know, that the rule of law prevails in India. (Para 220) Therefore, it is held that a statute depriving a person of his property is amenable to judicial review on the grounds discussed herein. Karnataka Roerich and Devikarani Roerich Estate (Acquisition and Transfer) Act, 1996 enacted with dominant purpose of protecting and preserving land used for linealo cultivation as part of agrarian reform, and ancillary to said purpose, also proposing preservation of certain valuables belonging to landowners, held, nonetheless saved by Art. 31-A(l)(a) - Hence, not subject to judicial review under Arts. 14 or 19 - Words and Phrases - "Estate" [Paras 111 to 118, 88 and 22l(c) & (d)] Held: The plea of repugnancy can be urged only if both the legislations fall under the Concurrent List. Under Article 254 of the Constitution, a State law passed in respect of a subject-matter comprised in List III would be invalid if its provisions are repugnant to a law passed on the same subject by Parliament and that too only if both the laws cannot exist together. (Para 107) The question of repugnancy under Article 254 of the Constitution arises when the provisions of both laws are fully inconsistent or are absolutely irreconcilable and it is impossible without disturbing the other, or conflicting results are produced, when both the statutes covering the same field are applied to a given set of facts. Repugnancy between the two statutes would arise if there is a direct conflict between the two provisions and the law made by Parliament and the law made by the State Legislature occupy the same field. (Para 108) Deep Chand v. State of UP., AIR 1959 SC 648; Prem Nath Kaul v. State of J&K, AIR 1959 SC 749 : 1959 Supp (2) SCR 270; Ukha Kolhe v. State of Karnataka, (1990) 2 sec 562, affirmed The test to determine whether the two legislations cover or relate to the same subject-matter is to find out the dominant intention of the two legislations and if the dominant intention of the two legislations is different and they cover different subject-matter then merely because the two legislations refer to some allied or cognate subjects, they do not cover the same field. (Para 109) A provision in one legislation to give effect to its dominant purpose may incidentally be on the same subject as covered by the provision of the other legislation, but such partial coverage of the same area in a different context and to achieve a different purpose does not bring about repugnancy which is intended to be covered by Article 254(2). Of late, right to property parted company with the other two rights under the Indian Constitution and took the position of a statutory right. Since ancient times, debates are going on as to whether the right to property is a "natural" tight or merely a creation of "social convention" and "positive law" which reflects the centrality and uniqueness of that right. Property tights at times are compared to right to life which determine access to the basic means of sustenance and considered as prerequisite to the meaningful exercise of other rights guaranteed under A1ticle 21. Grotius sets two conditions on the exercise of the power of eminent domain: the first requisite is public advantage and then that compensation from the public funds be made, if possible, to the one who has lost his right. Application of the above principle varies from country to country. German, U.S. and Australian Constitutions bar uncompensated takings. Canada's Constitution, however, does not contain the equivalent of the taking clause, and eminent domain is solely a matter of statute law. City of New London, 162 L Ed 2d 439: 545 US 469 (2004), considered Eminent domain is distinguishable alike from the police power, by which restiiction are imposed on private property in the public interest e.g. in connection with health, sanitation, zoning regulation, urban planning and so on, from the power of taxation, by which the owner of private property is compelled to contribute a portion of it for the public purposes and from the war power, involving the destruction of private property in the course of military operations.
